issue.title: Improvements to `<sl-menu>` when used inside of `<sl-dropdown>`
issue.body:
This is a 3.0 milestone because it will likely result in breaking changes. Some valid concerns have been raised about dropdown menus. Here are some of the open questions:

**Does it make sense to combine `<sl-dropdown>` and `<sl-menu>`?**

Dropdown was created at a time before we have `<sl-popup>` which handles all the position and whatnot. It's primary use case is as a dropdown menu, but it can be used as a low-level component with any contents. This flexibility is nice, but leaves room for user error, especially in terms of accessibility. Slimming down the use case would let us consolidate dropdown, menu, menu item, and menu label into fewer components.

```html
<sl-dropdown>
  <sl-dropdown-item>Item 1</sl-dropdown-item>
  <sl-dropdown-item>Item 2</sl-dropdown-item>
  <sl-dropdown-item>Item 3</sl-dropdown-item>
</sl-dropdown>
```

This would effectively eliminate menu and menu item, which people frequently mistake for nav menus.

We can optionally group them with a separate component like `<optgroup>`:

```html
<sl-dropdown>
  <sl-dropdown-group label="Group 1">
    <sl-dropdown-item>Item 1</sl-dropdown-item>
    <sl-dropdown-item>Item 2</sl-dropdown-item>
  </sl-dropdown-group>

  <sl-dropdown-group label="Group 2">
    <sl-dropdown-item>Item 3</sl-dropdown-item>
    <sl-dropdown-item>Item 4</sl-dropdown-item>
  </sl-dropdown-group>
</sl-dropdown>
```

This would make it much easier to support `menuitemcheckbox` and `menuitemradio` controls inside dropdown menus accessibly.

**Menu Items need to not steal focus on hover**

Another issue we have today is that menu items steal focus when hovering. This messes with the browser's `:focus-visible` heuristics and causes issues such as #1676. It also causes problems when trying to use dropdown + menu items along with a search filter, as focus is unexpectedly removed on hover. It's worth noting that we could probably build in an accessible search filter if we were to combine these components, which has been requested a number of times.

Given the way menus and menu items currently work, I don't see a way to solve this without a breaking change. (Granted, I haven't spent a ton of time on it either.)

I believe making menu items direct children of the dropdown would make this easier to solve.

---

If you have any thoughts, feedback, or concerns please post them below.

comment.body: Would love to see other use cases ☺️

commits.message: only emit sl-change when you stop dragging

issue.title: only emit sl-change when you stop dragging
issue.body:
Fixes #1680 

`sl-input` will work the same.

`sl-change` only fires when dragging has stopped.

This aligns much closer to how typical "sliders" work.

pull_request.title: only emit sl-change when you stop dragging
pull_request.body:
Fixes #1680 

`sl-input` will work the same.

`sl-change` only fires when dragging has stopped.

This aligns much closer to how typical "sliders" work.

issue.body:
This is a 3.0 milestone because it will likely result in breaking changes. Some valid concerns have been raised about dropdown menus. Here are some of the open questions:

Dropdown was created at a time before we have `<sl-popup>` which handles all the position and whatnot. It's primary use case is as a dropdown menu, but it can be used as a low-level component with any contents. This flexibility is nice, but leaves room for user error, especially in terms of accessibility. Slimming down the use case would let us consolidate dropdown, menu, menu item, and menu label into fewer components.

```html
<sl-dropdown>
```

```html
<sl-dropdown>
```

issue.title: Event sl-invalid is not dispatched properly

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Things that aren't working right in the library.

labels.name: waiting on element internals
labels.description: Issues to tackle once ElementInternals lands in all supported browsers.

issue.body:
It seems that the `sl-invalid` event is not dispatched properly => should be dispatched for all invalid fields in a form, but seems just to be dispatched once (at least in certain cases).
Please see this demo: http://jsbin.com/ruqufoyuyo/1/edit?html,output

I've not evaluated the cause yet, but I guess, the bug is inside of Shoelace code that I've written myself.
I'll check this as soon as I have time to do so, but first I wanted to ask you @claviska, whether it still makes sense to fix issues in the "associative forms workaround logic", as this will be replaced with "real" associative forms logic soon (while the second question would be: What does "soon" mean?).

issue.title: Event sl-invalid is not dispatched properly

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Things that aren't working right in the library.

labels.name: waiting on element internals
labels.description: Issues to tackle once ElementInternals lands in all supported browsers.

issue.body:
It seems that the `sl-invalid` event is not dispatched properly => should be dispatched for all invalid fields in a form, but seems just to be dispatched once (at least in certain cases).
Please see this demo: http://jsbin.com/ruqufoyuyo/1/edit?html,output

I've not evaluated the cause yet, but I guess, the bug is inside of Shoelace code that I've written myself.
I'll check this as soon as I have time to do so, but first I wanted to ask you @claviska, whether it still makes sense to fix issues in the "associative forms workaround logic", as this will be replaced with "real" associative forms logic soon (while the second question would be: What does "soon" mean?).

comment.body: I think we're going to have to live with this behavior until we rework forms with ElementInternals. It's finally in all browsers — most recently in Safari. At that time, we'll be reviewing all form controls to make sure they function as expected and more similar to native inputs.

issue.title: Light DOM styling strategy for avoiding FOUC

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: Issues that require new docs or updates to existing docs.

issue.body:
Something that comes up a lot in discussions around web components is the problem of FOUC (Flash of Unstyled Content).

Two solutions typically get proposed (other than simply hiding things altogether until component rendering JS is complete):

* We can "SSR" the component and use Declarative Shadow DOM. That way the template + styles is included in the HTML sent to the browser to be rendered. This would be the "maximum fidelity" solution.
* We can add extra light DOM stylings using `:not(:defined)` so that at least things don't initially look terrible or cause layout thrashing. This would be a "medium fidelity" solution.

Obviously the first option is superior if it could be managed. But I think the second option is actually more feasible for many projects…certainly for right now as the SSR story is still under development (#778), and certainly in any case where it's actually difficult/impossible to use a server-side JS rendering pipeline.

Here's a very quick pass at me trying to style an `sl-card` using only light DOM. https://codepen.io/jaredcwhite/pen/rNvpgwR

Rather than leaving this process up to individual consumers of Shoelace, I wonder if we couldn't include—for at least some components where it makes sense—a global light DOM stylesheet of undefined styles, with the goal being to provide basic reproduction of border/spacing/typography/colors. As you can see with the linked demo, uncommenting out the script tag and comparing both versions is no longer a huge difference (the rating component is goofy but I spent almost no time with it).

I understand this would be lots of extra work, and also extra CSS bundle size for perhaps not much gain (why style a bunch of stuff only for it to be seen for perhaps only a few hundred ms?). But given the challenges with SSR/DSD, and fact that it won't be a total panacea for _everyone_ any time in the foreseeable future, this might be a solution worth investing in.

Thoughts?

issue.title: Light DOM styling strategy for avoiding FOUC

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: Issues that require new docs or updates to existing docs.

issue.body:
Something that comes up a lot in discussions around web components is the problem of FOUC (Flash of Unstyled Content).

Two solutions typically get proposed (other than simply hiding things altogether until component rendering JS is complete):

* We can "SSR" the component and use Declarative Shadow DOM. That way the template + styles is included in the HTML sent to the browser to be rendered. This would be the "maximum fidelity" solution.
* We can add extra light DOM stylings using `:not(:defined)` so that at least things don't initially look terrible or cause layout thrashing. This would be a "medium fidelity" solution.

Obviously the first option is superior if it could be managed. But I think the second option is actually more feasible for many projects…certainly for right now as the SSR story is still under development (#778), and certainly in any case where it's actually difficult/impossible to use a server-side JS rendering pipeline.

Here's a very quick pass at me trying to style an `sl-card` using only light DOM. https://codepen.io/jaredcwhite/pen/rNvpgwR

Rather than leaving this process up to individual consumers of Shoelace, I wonder if we couldn't include—for at least some components where it makes sense—a global light DOM stylesheet of undefined styles, with the goal being to provide basic reproduction of border/spacing/typography/colors. As you can see with the linked demo, uncommenting out the script tag and comparing both versions is no longer a huge difference (the rating component is goofy but I spent almost no time with it).

I understand this would be lots of extra work, and also extra CSS bundle size for perhaps not much gain (why style a bunch of stuff only for it to be seen for perhaps only a few hundred ms?). But given the challenges with SSR/DSD, and fact that it won't be a total panacea for _everyone_ any time in the foreseeable future, this might be a solution worth investing in.

Thoughts?

comment.body:
There's also SSR via [DSD](https://developer.chrome.com/en/articles/declarative-shadow-dom/) for those brave enough to implement it. Hopefully metaframeworks start to implement it since 1) it's been standardized and 2) Firefox has begun work to implement it.

I don't think there's anything actionable at this point since we're already documenting some approaches, so I'm going to close this out.

issue.title: Remove getOffset function used by scrollIntoView
